stem: What is significant about the topmost layer in a container? Choose all that are true (2 correct answers).
options/0/title: The topmost layer's contents are ephemeral. When the container is deleted the contents will be lost.
options/1/title: Reading from or writing to the topmost layer requires special software libraries.
options/2/title: Reading from or writing to the topmost layer requires special privileges.
options/3/title: An application running in a container can only modify the topmost layer.

stem: Why do Linux containers use union file systems?
options/0/title: To control an application's maximum consumption of CPU time and memory
options/0/rationale: Sorry, that's not correct. Linux cgroups provide this benefit.
options/1/title: To give a container its own virtual memory address space
options/1/rationale: Sorry, that's not correct. Linux processes provide this benefit.
options/2/title: To control an application's ability to see parts of the directory tree and IP addresses
options/2/rationale: Sorry, that's not correct. Linux namespaces provide this benefit.
options/3/title: To efficiently encapsulate applications and their dependencies into a set of clean, minimal layers
